data.author: William Faulkner
data.title: Absalom, Absalom!
data.description: Absalom, Absalom! is a novel by the American author William Faulkner, first published in 1936. Taking place before, during, and after the Civil War, it is a story about three families of the American South, with a focus on the life of Thomas Sutpen.

data.author: Henrik Ibsen
data.title: A Doll's House
data.description: A Doll's House is a three-act play written by Norway's Henrik Ibsen. It premiered at the Royal Theatre in Copenhagen, Denmark, on 21 December 1879, having been published earlier that month. The play is set in a Norwegian town circa 1879.

data.author: Marcel Proust
data.title: In Search of Lost Time
data.description: In Search of Lost Time —also translated as Remembrance of Things Past—is a novel in seven volumes, written by Marcel Proust.

data.author: Leo Tolstoy
data.title: Anna Karenina
data.description: Anna Karenina is a novel by the Russian author Leo Tolstoy, first published in book form in 1878. Many writers consider Anna Karenina the greatest work of literature ever and Tolstoy himself called it his first true novel.

data.author: Toni Morrison
data.title: Beloved
data.description: Beloved is a 1987 novel by the American writer Toni Morrison. Set after the American Civil War, it is inspired by the life of Margaret Garner, an African American who escaped slavery in Kentucky in late January 1856 by crossing the Ohio River to Ohio, a free state.

data.author: Alfred Döblin
data.title: Berlin Alexanderplatz
data.description: Berlin Alexanderplatz, originally broadcast in 1980, is a 14-part West German television miniseries, set in 1920s Berlin and adapted and directed by Rainer Werner Fassbinder from Alfred Döblin's novel of the same name. It stars Günter Lamprecht, Hanna Schygulla, Barbara Sukowa, Elisabeth Trissenaar and Gottfried John.

data.author: José Saramago
data.title: Blindness
data.description: Blindness is a novel by Portuguese author José Saramago. It is one of his most famous novels, along with The Gospel According to Jesus Christ and Baltasar and Blimunda. In 1998, Saramago received the Nobel Prize for Literature, and Blindness was one of his works noted by the committee when announcing the award

data.author: Saadi
data.title: Bostan
data.description: The Bostan is a book of poetry by the Persian poet Saadi, completed in 1257 CE and dedicated to the Salghurid Atabeg Sa'd I or Sa'd II. Bustan is considered one of two major works of Saadi. It was Saadi's first work, and its title means the orchard.

data.author: Thomas Mann
data.title: The Magic Mountain
data.description: The Magic Mountain (German: Der Zauberberg) is a novel by Thomas Mann, first published in German in November 1924.

data.author: Naguib Mahfouz
data.title: Children of Gebelawi
data.description: The Magic Mountain is a novel by Thomas Mann, first published in German in November 1924. It is widely considered to be one of the most influential works of twentieth-century German literature. Mann started writing what was to become The Magic Mountain in 1912.

data.author: Italo Svevo
data.title: Confessions of Zeno
data.description: Zeno's Conscience is a novel by Italian writer Italo Svevo. The main character is Zeno Cosini, and the book is the fictional character's memoirs that he keeps at the insistence of his psychiatrist. Throughout the novel, we learn about his father, his business, his wife, and his tobacco habit.

data.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
data.title: Crime and Punishment
data.description: Crime and Punishment is a novel by the Russian author Fyodor Dostoevsky. It was first published in the literary journal The Russian Messenger in twelve monthly installments during 1866. It was later published in a single volume.

data.author: Nikolai Gogol
data.title: Dead Souls
data.description: Dead Souls is a novel by Nikolai Gogol, first published in 1842, and widely regarded as an exemplar of 19th-century Russian literature. The novel chronicles the travels and adventures of Pavel Ivanovich Chichikov and the people whom he encounters. These people are typical of the Russian middle-class of the time.

data.author: Lu Xun
data.title: Diary of a Madman
data.description: Diary of a Madman is a farcical short story by Nikolai Gogol. Along with The Overcoat and The Nose, Diary of a Madman is considered to be one of Gogol's greatest short stories

data.author: Miguel de Cervantes
data.title: Don Quijote De La Mancha
data.description: The Ingenious Gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha, or just Don Quixote, is a Spanish novel by Miguel de Cervantes. Published in two parts, in 1605 and 1615, Don Quixote is the most influential work of literature from the Spanish Golden Age and the entire Spanish literary canon.

data.author: Michel de Montaigne
data.title: Essays
data.description: Massive volume Essais contains some of the most influential essays ever written. Montaigne had a direct influence on Western writers, including Francis

data.author: Hans Christian Andersen
data.title: Fairy tales
data.description: My Jumbo Book Of Fairy Tales has a compilation of eight classic fairy tales that are loved by the children. Written in simple English and in clear words, the book also contains wonderful illustrations that would help the children enjoy every bit of the tales profoundly.

data.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
data.title: Faust
data.description: Faust is one of the pillars of Western literature. This classic drama presents the story of the scholar Faust, tempted into a contract with the Devil in return for a life of sensuality and power.

data.author: Jorge Luis Borges
data.title: Ficciones
data.description: Fictions is a collection of short stories by Argentine writer and poet Jorge Luis Borges, produced between 1941 and 1956. The English translation of Fictions was published in 1962, the same year as Labyrinths, a separate compilation of Borges's translated works.

data.author: François Rabelais
data.title: Gargantua and Pantagruel
data.description: The Life of Gargantua and of Pantagruel (French: La vie de Gargantua et de Pantagruel) is a pentalogy of novels written in the 16th century by François Rabelais, telling the adventures of two giants.
